Yes, there have been several high-profile cases of match-fixing in badminton in recent years. Some of the notable cases are:

1. The 2012 London Olympics: Eight badminton players were disqualified for trying to lose their matches intentionally to get easier opponents in the next round.

2. The 2014 Uber Cup: Two Thai badminton players were suspended for two years after confessing to match-fixing during the tournament.

3. The 2018 SaarLorLux Open: Four badminton players were charged with match-fixing by the Badminton World Federation (BWF), and the case is still ongoing.

4. The 2019 Southeast Asian Games: Two Indonesian badminton players were banned for life by the Indonesian Badminton Association after being found guilty of match-fixing.

5. The 2020 YONEX German Open: Two badminton players from Germany were suspended by the BWF after being found guilty of match-fixing during the tournament.

These cases demonstrate that match-fixing is a serious issue in badminton and that the authorities are taking steps to root out these practices and punish those responsible.
